title: The Best Way to Start a New Habit
summary: Implementation intentions and habit stacking are powerful strategies for starting new habits. By linking new behaviors to specific cues and existing routines, you make habits more automatic and easier to remember. The key is to be specific about when and where you'll perform your new habit.
keyIdeas: Implementation intentions use the formula: 'I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].'
Habit stacking links new habits to existing ones using: 'After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].'
Specificity increases the likelihood of following through.
The best time to start a habit is now, not when conditions are perfect.
Start with obvious cues that are impossible to miss.
Stacking habits creates a chain reaction of positive behaviors.
The more specific your plan, the more automatic your habit becomes.
examples: After I pour my morning coffee, I will meditate for one minute.
When I arrive home from work, I will change into my workout clothes.
After I finish dinner, I will read one page of my book.
exercises: Write an implementation intention for a habit you want to start.
Create a habit stack by linking a new habit to an existing daily routine.
Identify 3 potential cues in your environment for a new habit.
reflections: What existing habit could you use as a cue for a new behavior?
How can you make your habit cues more obvious in your environment?
